However, Nanjo only appeared calm next to Hideyoshi, who simply couldn't suppress his agitation and fear.

In fact, Nanjo had also received a huge shock, and his face was a deathly pale.

そんな中だからこそ、リーダーシップを発揮しようと奮い立つのだろうか。
Maybe that atmosphere was why she tried to rise to the challenge and take charge.

夏妃は普段と変わらぬ態度のように見えた。
そしてきびきびと指示をする。
Natsuhi appeared to be unchanged from her normal attitude.

And she briskly gave directions.

「……私はお父様のところへ行ってきます。…源次は急ぎ、警察へ連絡を。」
"......I will go see Father. Genji, quickly contact the police."

「かしこまりました…。」
"Certainly..."

「私も一緒させていただいていいかしら、夏妃姉さん？　……蔵臼兄さんがいなくなった以上、お父様の補佐は私の仕事だもの。その私が夏妃姉さんに任せっきりでここでくつろいでるわけにはいかないわ。」
"I wonder if you would allow me to tag along, Natsuhi nee-san? ......Since Krauss nii-san is now gone, the task of aiding Father has been left to me. It would be improper of me to relax here while relying entirely on you."

このような事態に何と逞しいことかと、夏妃は絶句する。
Natsuhi was struck speechless by Eva's aggressive move in a situation like this.

蔵臼が死んだなら、次に指揮を執るのはその妻ではなく、次の序列である自分だと、そう主張したいらしい。
She seemed to be claiming that, with Krauss dead, the one to take responsibility shouldn't be his wife, but herself, the next highly ranked in the family.

…あるいは、この非常事態に夏妃が自分を差し置いて切り盛りしているのが気に入らないのか。
...Or maybe she hadn't been at all happy when Natsuhi took command without reference to her in such an extreme situation.

もっとも、絵羽とて直前までショックで頭が真っ白だった。
…夏妃が指示を始めて、初めて我に帰ったのだ。
However, even Eva's mind had been blank from shock until a moment ago.

...She only came to her senses after Natsuhi started giving orders.

「………………………。……お好きになさるといいでしょう。」
"...............Just do as you like."

夏妃はそれ以上、何も言わず、先に歩き出す。
その後に絵羽も付いていくのだった。
Natsuhi started walking without saying a word more.

Eva followed behind her.

…それと入れ替わるように、客間に熊沢が駆け込んできた。
...As they did, Kumasawa ran into the parlor.

普段は走るような人ではないので、何かあったのかと思うのが正常な感覚だが、…今は誰もがショックに打ちひしがれていて、その程度のことを気には留めなかった。
She usually wasn't the kind of person to run around, so under normal conditions, most people would have taken her entrance as sign that something was the matter, ...but because everyone was still stricken with shock, they hardly even noticed her.

「……あ、あの、
…奥様、
…奥様………！」
"......U-Umm,

...Madam,

...Madam......!"




「夏妃姉さんなら、お父さんのところへ行ったで。すぐ戻ってくるやろ。…どないしたんや、熊沢さん。」
"If you're lookin' for Natsuhi nee-san, she went to see Father. She'll probably be back soon. ...What happened, Kumasawa-san?"

「そ、それが、………食堂に、……血が…、……血が……！」
"Y-You see, ...in the dining hall, there was......blood, ...blood...!"

　客間にいた全員の耳がびくりと震える。
The ears of everyone in the parlor twitched.

誰もが思った。
…聞き間違えであってほしいと。
Everyone thought the same thing.

`I hope I misheard that.'

……どんな器にだって入る限界の量があるように、…もうこれ以上の惨劇を受け容れることのできる器など、誰にもなかった。
...Any container can only hold so much, ...and no one here would be capable of handling yet another tragedy.

だから思った。聞き間違えであってほしいと……。
So they all thought it. `I hope I misheard that'......

「な、……何やて、
……食堂…？」
"...Wh-What happened...

...in the dining hall...?"

「朝食の準備に…、
食堂に配膳に行ったら…、
……あわわわわわ…わわ…。」
"When I went to the dining hall...

to set up for breakfast...

......Awawawawawa... wawa..."

真っ先に走ったのは譲治だった。
The first one to start running was George.

その荒々しい足音に我に帰った秀吉と南條が後を追う。戦人たちもそれに続く。
His harsh footsteps jogged Hideyoshi and Nanjo to their senses, and they chased after him. Battler and the others followed.

彼らは次々に食堂に飛び込むが、熊沢が真っ青になるほどの変化は見つけられなかった。
They flew into the dining hall one after another, but they didn't find any change that might have caused Kumasawa to go pale.

…あの倉庫の凄惨さを知る者たちにとって、それは一瞬、拍子抜けだった。
...To those who had viewed that gruesome scene in the storehouse, it was a bit of an anticlimax.

だが、後から来た熊沢が指差して教えてくれた。
……確かに、床に血の跡が残っていたのである。
However, Kumasawa, who had followed them, pointed it out.

......There really were some traces of blood remaining on the floor.

…あの惨状を思えばそれは決して派手ではない。
...Compared to that terrible scene, it wasn't very impressive.

…しかし冷静に考えたなら、これは相当の出血を物語るのに間違いなかった。
...However, if you calmly thought about it, this definitely indicated the loss of a lot of blood.

「…………ここにも血溜まりがあるよ。…………これは一体……。」
"......There's another puddle of blood over here. ......What in the world..."

「……だいぶ、時間が経っているように見えますな…。……おそらく、昨夜……ここで殺されたんだと見て良いでしょう…。」
"......It appears that a great deal of time has passed... ......It's probably safe to say that they were killed here last night..."

「そ、そういうことになるんやろな…。…わしらは昨夜はずっと食堂で話し合いをしとった…。そして、ここに何者かが押し入ったに違いない…。」
"I-It definitely looks that way... ...We were talkin' together in the dinin' hall until late into the night... After that, someone must've forced their way in..."

「父さんたちが打ち合わせを抜けて休んだのは何時だっけ……？」
"Dad, when did you and Mom slip out of the meeting and go to sleep...?"

「…うむ…。昨夜の２４時を少し過ぎたくらいの頃や…。
"...Hmm... It was a little past midnight...

……だから、
…その後に、
…と考えるんが妥当やろな…。」
...So,

...we should probably assume...

...it happened after that..."

「………マジかよ…。………勘弁してくれよ………。」
"......Are you kidding me...? ......Gimme a break......"

「お嬢様、……しっかり……。」
"Milady, ...please, stay strong..."

「…へへへへ…。…俺はもう、さっきの倉庫でこの世の地獄ってヤツを拝んじまったから、今さらこのくらいじゃ堪えねぇぜ…。」
"...Heheheheh... ...After seeing that hell on earth in the storehouse, this is nothing..."

「……そうかよ、良かったな…。私は頭がどうにかなっちまいそうだぜ…。……ここは食堂だぜ？　私は毎日ここで食事をして、学校のことをぼやいたり、宿題のことをぼやいたり、……親父に学校の成績の話をされたり、
……そういうところなんだぜ……？」
"......Really? Good for you... I feel like my head's gonna explode... ...This is the dining hall, right? Every day, this is where I'd eat, complain about school, complain about homework, ...talk to my Dad about my grades...

...That's what this place is to me..."

「…………お嬢様。これ以上、ここに居るのはよくありません。…客間へ戻りましょう。」
"......Milady, it wouldn't be good to remain here any longer. ...Let's return to the parlor."

「俺も同感さ…。………秀吉伯父さん！　この部屋は多分、警察にとって重要な意味があると思います。俺たちが踏み荒らしちまうのはマズイじゃないんすか？」
"I agree... ......Uncle Hideyoshi! I think this room'll be really important to the police. Don't you think it'd be bad if we trampled all over it?"

真っ青になって震える朱志香の肩を、嘉音と共に抱き、戦人は少しだけ力強い声で提案する。
Battler proposed this in a slightly firm voice as, along with Kanon, he grabbed the pale and shaking Jessica's shoulders.

「………戦人さんの言う通りですな。この部屋にこれ以上、好んで居続けることはありますまい。」
"......Everything is just as Battler-san has said. There is nothing more to be gained from remaining in this room."

南條が全員の蒼白な顔を見て言う。
Nanjo spoke while looking at everyone's pale faces.

……あの倉庫の惨状は、この世のものとは思えないものではあっても、少なくともこことは離れた場所で、切り離して逃げてきたという気持ちで誰もが自分を納得させていた。
......Even though that horrible scene in the storehouse felt like something not of this world, at least then we'd been able to leave, to cut ourselves off from that place and run away. Everyone had shared in that feeling.

……でもこの食堂は違う。
......However, this dining hall was different.

母屋である屋敷の中にあり、…そして朱志香の言う通り、この屋敷の中でも心落ち着く場所のひとつだったはずだ。昨日、親類みんなでランチやディナーを楽しんだ場所だ。
It was in the mansion, the main building on this estate, ...and as Jessica had said, it should have been one of the most calming places even inside the mansion. It was where all of the relatives had eaten lunch and dinner yesterday.

……そこが、血で汚されていることの衝撃は、倉庫の惨状を再び思い出させ、自分たちが決して惨劇現場から逃れてはいないことを無理やり認識させるのだ……。
......The shock of seeing this place smeared with blood reminded us of that horrible spectacle in the storehouse...and forced us to accept that we hadn't really been able to run away from the scene of that tragedy......

「…うむ。わしも同感や…。この部屋には犯人の痕跡が残ってるかもわからんしな！
素人のわしらがかき回すべきとちゃうで。…早ぅ出るんや。早う早ぅ！」
"...Hmm. I agree too... The culprit might've left traces in this room!

Amateurs like us shouldn't stir the place up. ...Let's leave quickly. Quickly, quickly!"

秀吉も戦人の言う意味を理解し、急き立てるように食堂から出ろ出ろと叫ぶ。
Hideyoshi also understood the meaning of what Battler had said...and pushed everyone to hurry out of the dining hall.

…これ以上、血を見るのは今の自分たちには酷に過ぎることなのだ。
...The way we were then, looking at that blood any longer would've been too harsh.

その言葉に逆らう者はいなかった。
皆、先を争うように食堂を後にする。
…………まるで、最後の人はこの部屋に取り残されて閉じ込められてしまうかのように…。
Nobody went against his words.

Everyone raced each other out of the dining hall.

......It was almost as though the last person in the room would be trapped in there, all alone.

廊下で、未だ震えて壁にもたれかかる熊沢に肩を貸すと、一同は客間に戻ってきた。
Once in the hallway, we lent a hand to Kumasawa, who was still trembling and leaning against the wall, and we all headed back to the parlor together.

…そこへ源次が戻ってくる。
...Then, Genji returned.

「……おお、源次さん。警察に連絡はつきましたか。」
"......Oh, Genji-san. Were you able to contact the police?"

「………………それが、申し訳ございません。
"............As to that, I'm afraid I must apologize.

…無線機の故障か、それ以外の理由によるものかわかりませんが…、」
...I don't know if it was a failure of the radio or something else that caused it, but..."

「何や…、警察に連絡がつかんのか…！！　電話も無線もどっちも駄目なんか！」
"What the... So you couldn't contact the police...?!! Both the phone and the radio failed?!"

「…申し訳ございません。月曜の朝に船が来ることになっていますので、その船の通信機を借りることができると思います。」
"...My apologies. A boat will be arriving on Monday morning, and I believe we will be able to borrow their communications equipment."

「この島には船はないんか？！　新島の警察署までちょっくら行ってくることはでけんのか！」
"Isn't there a boat on this island?! Can't we just take a little trip out to the Niijima Police Department?!"

「…秀吉さん、この天気では無理だ…。少なくとも、台風が通り過ぎるまではどうにもなりません。」
"...Hideyoshi-san, that would be impossible with this weather... At the very least, we can't do anything until the typhoon passes us by."

「蔵臼さまのボートは今、修理中で島にありません…。ですので、月曜の船を待つ他ないかと……。」
"Krauss-sama's boat is being repaired and is not on the island... Therefore, we must wait for the boat coming on Monday......"

「そ、そんなアホな話があるか…！　６人も死んだんやで！！　そして電話も無線も通じず、船もない！　台風が過ぎて船が来るまで…、つまり明日の朝までわしらは警察にも連絡できず、この島におれっちゅうことなんか？！」
"H-How could this happen...?! Six people are dead!! The phones and radio aren't working, and there's no boat! So, until the typhoon passes and the boat comes...in other words, until tomorrow mornin', we're gonna be stuck here on this island, unable to contact the police, aren't we?!"

「………ってことはつまり。……俺たちだけじゃなく、
…伯父さんたちを殺した犯人も、この島から出られず、足止めってことだな…。」
"......Which means that...not just us,

...but the criminal who killed everyone is also confined to this island..."

「……そういうことになるね。……みんなを殺した犯人は、まだこの島にいる。」
"...That certainly follows. ...The culprit who killed everyone is still here on the island."

「お、……親父たちを殺したヤツは、この島から逃げ出せず、まだ潜んでやがるってことかよ…。
"...S-So the bastard who killed Dad and the others must still be hiding somewhere, unable to escape...

……くそ、くそくそくそ！！　見つけ出してやるぜ、警察になんか引き渡すもんか！！
...Damn it, dammitdammitdammit!!! I'll catch that bastard, no way I'll hand him over to the police!!

私がこの手で八つ裂きにしてやる…！！！　ううぅうぅぅ！！！」
I'll slice him to bits myself...!!! Aaaaaaaaaaaaahh!!!"

「………………………………。」
"....................."

真里亞はようやく、客間の様子がおかしいことに気付く。
Maria had finally realized that something odd was happening in the parlor.

…おかしいというよりは、彼らが自分だけがわからない何かで盛り上がっていることに対し疎外感を感じ不愉快に思った、という方が正しいだろうか。
...Rather than noticing something odd, it was probably better to say she felt unhappy and neglected, since everyone was getting so excited about something only she didn't know about.

「………うー。…朱志香お姉ちゃん。誰か死んじゃったの？」
".........Uu-. ...Jessica onee-chan, did someone die?"

本当にきょとんとした言い方。
The way she spoke was completely calm.

…まるでテレビドラマの登場人物の話をしているように他人事だった。
...Just as though she was talking about someone who had appeared on a television drama, as though it was someone else's problem.

…それが朱志香には気に入らなかったのだろう。
...Jessica probably didn't like that.

……これほど悲しみに暮れる自分を見てそれが理解できないのかと言わんばかりに、真里亞に食って掛かる。
...As though trying to say `Can't you tell just by looking at me, overwhelmed with grief?!', she flared up at Maria.

「死んじまったぜ、みんなみんな！！　私の親父も、戦人の父さんと母さんも！！　郷田さんも紗音も！！　そして真里亞の母さんも！！」
"They all died, everyone, everyone!! My dad and Battler's parents!! Gohda-san and Shannon!! And even your mother, too!!"

「よすんだ、朱志香ちゃん…！！　悲しいのは君だけじゃない…！」
"Stop it, Jessica-chan...!! You aren't the only one who's sad...!"

「…真里亞さん…。ショックだろうが聞いてください。……あなたのお母さんがな…。……死んでしまいました。」
"...Maria-san, ...I know this will come as a shock, but please listen. ...Your mother......has died."

「…………ママが死んじゃった？　……うー…？」
"......Mama died? ...Uu-...?"

「……あぁ、誰かに殺されちまった。…悲しいだろうがよ、心をしっかり…、」
"...Yeah, someone killed her. ...I know it's sad, but stay strong..."

「……………………何人、
死んじゃった？」
".........How many people...

died?"

「６人だぜ！！　６人だッ！　……くそくそくそ！　あんな残酷なことしやがって！！　程ってもんがあるだろうがよ、人間ならよ…！　誰だか知らねぇが、犯人は人間じゃねぇぜ！！　血の色が赤いわけがねぇ！！」
"Six people!! Six people! ...Dammitdammitdammit! How could anyone do something that cruel?!! There's a limit to how cruel you can be, if you're human...! I don't know who it is, but the culprit isn't human!! There's no way their blood is red!!"

「…………うー。犯人は人間じゃない。…＊が選んだ＊＊なだけ。」
"............Uu-. The culprit isn't human. ...It's just the **** chosen by the ****."

「え？　……………おい真里亞、
今、何て言った？」
"Huh? ......Hey, Maria,

did you say something just now?"

今、真里亞は何か言ったが、それが、会話の流れから想定される単語から大きくかけ離れていたため、一瞬、意味を理解できなかった。
Maria had just said something, but since the words were so remotely separated from the flow and context of the conversation, I couldn't understand them for a second.

それをもう一度聞きなおそうとした時、客間の入り口で夏妃伯母さんの大きな声が突然聞こえて驚かされた。
When I tried to ask her to repeat it again, I was shocked by the sudden sound of Aunt Natsuhi's loud voice coming from the entrance to the parlor.

祖父さまのところへ行っていた夏妃伯母さんと絵羽伯母さんが戻ってきたのだろう。
It looked like Aunt Natsuhi and Aunt Eva had returned from their trip to see Grandfather.

「無線でも連絡できない？！　………こんな時に使えなくて、何のための防災無線ですか！」
"You can't contact them, even with the radio?! ......If we can't use it at a time like this, why do we even have an emergency radio?!"

「……………申し訳ございません。毎年、保守点検はさせているはずなのですが…。」
"......My apologies. It was supposed to have a maintenance inspection every year..."

「ほら、光をチカチカさせるみたいな船舶信号ってあるじゃない？　そういうので向こうの島に連絡することはできないのかしら？」
"Wait, don't you have one of those boat signaling devices that makes a flashing light? Couldn't you use that to contact the next island?"

「……そのような設備はございません…。…申し訳ございません…。」
"...We do not have such equipment... ...My sincere apologies..."

そこへ、朝食を載せた配膳台車を押す熊沢がやって来る。
Just then, Kumasawa arrived, pushing a serving cart loaded with breakfast.

……あの食堂で食事などできるわけもないため、秀吉が客間へ運ぶよう指示したためだ。
......Since there was no way we'd be able to eat in the dining hall, Hideyoshi had ordered her to take it to the parlor.

「なぜ朝食をこちらに？」
"Why are we eating breakfast here?"

「……あぁあぁ、夏妃さん…、それは後で話す。それより絵羽、お父さんはどうなんや。」
"...Aaaahhh, Natsuhi-san, ...I'll tell you later. More importantly, Eva, how was Father?"

「ご一緒でないところを見ると、
………このような事態になっても、部屋から出ませんか…。」
"Judging by the fact that he is not with you,

......it seems he will not leave his room, not even for a situation like this..."

「いないわ。……部屋は空っぽだったのよ。」
"He wasn't there. ...The room was empty."




「なんやて…。こんな時にどこ行ったんや…！」
"What the... Where could he have gone at a time like this...?!"

「…………お館様が、書斎を出られたというのですか…？」
"......Do you mean to say the Master has left his study...?"

「…そうです。私も驚いています…。いつの間に部屋を出たのやら……。あなたたちに心当たりはないのですか？」
"...That is correct. I was surprised myself... I wonder when he left his room... Do any of you have an idea?"

夏妃はそう言い、源次と嘉音を見る。
Natsuhi looked at Genji and Kanon as she said this.

…片翼の鷲を許された直属の使用人なら行きそうな場所を知っているのではないか、ということだろう。
Maybe she was trying to ask whether the servants who served directly under the One-Winged Eagle knew of a place he might go.

………しかし、実際は逆のようだった。
.........However, it was probably the other way around.

…金蔵のことを知り尽くしている彼らだからこそ、むしろ部屋を出ることの方がありえない、という顔つきだった。
Their faces made it clear that those who knew Kinzo best...realized even more than the rest how impossible it was for him to leave his room.

「………僕たちにも、見当がつきません。」
".........Even we have no idea."

「…ご存知の通り、お館様はあの書斎の中に、お休みの場所からご不浄まで全てを設けさせました。お館様があの部屋をお出になることなどよっぽどの事がない限り、考えられません。」
"...As you all know, within that study, the Master had everything from a place to sleep to a bathroom. I couldn't imagine him leaving that room except for a significant reason."

「…………となると、…何や。その“よっぽどの事”があった、って考えるのが自然だっちゅうことになるんか…！」
"............In that case, what? Isn't it natural to assume that one of those `significant reasons' came up...?!"

「まだそうと決まったわけではありません！
"We still cannot be certain that's the case!

とにかく気まぐれな方ですから、現状をご存知なく、おひとりで散歩をされている可能性もあります。……仮にそうだとしたら、一刻も早く、現状をお知らせして、ご指示を仰がねばなりません。」
Anyway, he is a fickle person, so it's possible he went for a walk by himself, unaware of the current situation. ......If that is the case, then we must act in all haste to tell him what has happened and ask for instructions."

「……そうねぇ。………考えたくはないけど、…お父様の身に何かあったのかもしれないしねぇ…？」
"...That's right. ......Although I don't want to think about it, ...it's possible something has happened to him, isn't it...?"

「そのような不吉なことは考えたくもありません…！」
"I'd rather not even consider such a sinister possibility...!"

６人が無惨な死体で発見され、金蔵の姿が見えない。
その上、電話は故障し、無線も通じず、警察にも連絡が取れない。
No one had seen Kinzo since the discovery of those six terrible corpses.

On top of that, the phones were broken, the radio wouldn't reach anyone, and there was no way to contact the police.

…台風も明日には去り、船も来てくれるらしいが、……それまでこの島は、外部の誰にも頼れず、そして誰も逃げ出すことができないということだ。
...Apparently, the typhoon would leave tomorrow and a boat would come, ...but until then, no one could rely on anyone outside the island, nor could they escape the island.

誰もがあまりに突然の惨劇に、冷静さを失っていた。
The tragedy had hit everyone so abruptly that they'd lost all their composure.

…重苦しい沈黙と焦燥感。
...Everyone felt a heavy silence. Everyone was impatient.

…何かをしなくてはならないのに、何も思いつかず、ある者はイラつき、ある者は頭を抱えるだけ。
...Even though they needed to do something, they couldn't think of anything, so some of them held their heads in their arms while others got irritated.

………誰にも、…今、この六軒島で何が起こっているのか説明することはできなかった……。
.........Right now, no one could explain what was occurring on this island, Rokkenjima...

その後、熊沢さんが作ってくれた朝食を、客間でぼそぼそと食べた。
After that, we ate the breakfast Kumasawa-san had made, which felt dry and tasteless.

もちろん、あんなことがあった直後だ。
誰だって食欲などわかない。
Of course, this was right after something like that had happened.

No one felt particularly hungry.

…でも、食べなければ体が参ってしまうのは理屈でわかっている。
However, we understood logically that not eating would weaken our bodies.

…それに作ってくれた熊沢さんにも悪い。
...It would also be rude to Kumasawa-san, who had made the breakfast.

郷田さんが、凝りに凝った料理のために取り寄せただろう珍しい西洋野菜は、熊沢さんによって、和風に料理され、違和感のある彩りとなっていた。
Kumasawa-san had taken some unusual Western vegetables, ones that Gohda-san had probably ordered for his ultra-elaborate meals, and cooked them in a Japanese style, which made them turn an unpleasant color.

これらの材料によって、郷田さんがどんな料理を作るつもりだったのか…。今となっては想像することもできない。
As to what Gohda-san had been planning to cook with those ingredients, ...right then I couldn't even imagine it.

それを想像すれば、郷田さんの死に様が再び蘇り、口の中が酸っぱい何かで満たされる…。
If I did think about it, I'd be reminded of the way Gohda-san died, and a sour taste would fill the inside of my mouth...

みんなは一応、食べるふりだけするのだが、箸が進むはずもなかった。
Everyone pretended to eat for the time being, but of course, no one made much progress.

そして、現状についての周知が行われた。
Then, we began pooling our knowledge of our current situation.

まず、……蔵臼伯父さん、ウチの親父、霧江さん、楼座叔母さん、郷田さんに紗音ちゃんの６人が、薔薇庭園の倉庫で無惨な死体となって発見されたこと。
First off, ...six people, which included Uncle Krauss, my dad, Kyrie-san, Aunt Rosa, Gohda-san and Shannon-chan...had been found in the rose garden storehouse as brutally mutilated corpses.

にもかかわらず、電話も無線も使えず、警察への連絡が未だできないこと。
……つまり、ってことはこの台風が通り過ぎるまで、俺たちにできることは何もないってわけだ。
And yet, we still couldn't contact the police, since both the phones and the radio were unusable.

...So, until the typhoon passed, there was nothing we could do.

さらに、この事態に少しはリーダーシップを発揮してくれるかと期待した祖父さまはいつの間にかいなくなっていた。
Furthermore, Grandfather, who we might've hoped would be able to show a little leadership in this kind of a situation, had disappeared some time ago.

……郷田さんが朝食を作らなかったのだから、未だ空腹なはずで、単にぶらりと散歩に出ているだけなら、今頃空腹で向こうからぴーぴー言ってくるはずだ。
......Gohda-san hadn't made breakfast, so Grandfather's stomach must have been empty, and if he had just been taking a casual walk, we should've been able to hear him whining about how hungry he was by now.

にもかかわらず、
現れない。
And despite that,

he hadn't appeared.

……事件に巻き込まれた可能性は少なくなかった。
......There was more than a small chance that he'd gotten caught up in this crime.

夏妃伯母さんたちは、祖父さまを呼びに行った帰りに、その姿を探して各階に声を掛けたそうだが見つけられなかったという。
According to my aunts, on their way back from Kinzo's study, they'd searched for him, calling out on every floor, but were unable to find him.

…タイミング的に考えて、事件に関係があると考えるのが妥当だろう。
...Considering the timing of it all, it's only reasonable to assume that this disappearance had something to do with the crime.

食堂で殺されたと思われるうちの親父たちが、わざわざその遺体を倉庫に移されていたように、祖父さまもすでに殺されていて、その遺体が妙な場所に運び込まれていて、未だ発見されていないだけ…、というのは誰も口にしないが、非常に説得力のある想像だった…。
We figured Dad and the rest were probably killed in the dining hall and then painstakingly moved to the storehouse. So maybe, Grandfather has already been killed...and dragged to some strange place, which we simply haven't discovered yet... No one actually said it out loud, but this theory seemed extremely convincing...

「私たちは、お屋敷の戸締りを確認してきます。お父様も念入りに探さなければなりません。子どもたちはこの部屋を出ないように。
"We will go check that all of the windows and doors are locked. We must also conduct a thorough search for Father. The children must remain in this room...

絵羽さんと秀吉さんは、申し訳ありませんが、ここで子どもたちと一緒にいてください。南條先生もお願いいたします。」
Eva-san and Hideyoshi-san, I'm sorry, but please stay here with the children. I'd like to ask you the same, Doctor Nanjo."

「…わかりました。ここでお待ちしています……。」
"...I understand. I will wait here......"

夏妃伯母さんは、使用人たち、源次さんと熊沢さんと嘉音くんを従え、客間を出て行った。
Aunt Natsuhi followed the servants, Genji-san, Kumasawa-san, and Kanon-kun, out of the parlor.

残ったのは、絵羽伯母さんと秀吉伯父さん。南條先生と、俺たち子ども４人の合計７人だった。
All that was left was Aunt Eva, Uncle Hideyoshi, Doctor Nanjo, and the four of us children, a total of seven people.

「みんなで仲良く、テレビでも見て待ってよな。しっかし、日曜日の午前中はロクな番組やっとらへんなぁ。」
"Let's all stick together and maybe watch some television while we wait. Though I doubt we'll find anythin' good in the middle of the day on a Sunday."

秀吉伯父さんは暗くなった場を盛り上げようと、陽気そうに振舞う。
Uncle Hideyoshi started acting cheerfully, trying to brighten up this gloomy atmosphere.

「うー。ロクな番組、見る見る。うーうー！」
"Uu-. Good show, watch it, watch it. Uu-uu-!"

「おう、そうか。真里亞ちゃんはテレビ見るか。じゃあ伯父さんと一緒に見ようなぁ。」
"Oh, really? You wanna watch TV, Maria-chan? Then come and watch it with your uncle."

乗ってきたのは真里亞だけだった。
Maria was the only one who joined in.

…真里亞は母である楼座叔母さんが殺されたと教えられえても、特に感情のゆらめきを見せなかった。
...Even though Maria had been told of her mother's death, she didn't show the slightest flicker in her emotions.

…真里亞の９歳という年齢は、こんなにも幼いものだったのだろうか……。
...Was it really normal for a nine-year-old girl like Maria to act so much like a very young child...?

周りはとてもそういう気分になれず、各々がソファーに身を沈めて放心するのだった…。
Everyone else's mood failed to improve, and they each sank absentmindedly into their sofas...

「…………兄貴。聞いていいか？」
"......Aniki, can I ask you something?"

「…何だい？」
"...What is it?"

「……さっき倉庫で。兄貴は紗音ちゃんの指輪の話をしたよな。……あれ、贈ったのは兄貴か？」
"...Just now, in the storehouse... You said something about Shannon-chan and a ring. ...Did you give that to her?"

譲治の兄貴は応えなかったが、俯き、固く両目を瞑った。……それ以上明白な答えはなかった。
George-aniki didn't answer, but he hung his head and closed both of his eyes. ...There could be no clearer response.

「よせよ戦人。……少しは察しろよ。」
"Quit it, Battler. ...Figure it out yourself."

「……だな。悪ぃことを聞いたぜ。」
"...You're right. I shouldn't have asked."

「……………そうさ。僕だよ。………彼女に、
昨夜、求婚したんだ。…その時、指輪を渡した。……明日になったら、
それを好きな指にはめて、
返事としてくれって、……はは、キザったらしいことを言ってね。」
".........That's right. It was me. ......Last night,

I proposed to her. ...That was when I gave her the ring. ...I told her that tomorrow,

she should put it on whatever finger she wanted...

as her answer. ...Haha, guess it was a pretty pretentious thing to say."

……そして、その指輪は、
……紗音ちゃんの左手の薬指にあった。
...And that ring had been...

...on the ring finger of Shannon-chan's left hand.

「…………………私さ。…数年前から、紗音に相談を受けてたぜ。…譲治兄さんのことでさ。」
".........Well, ...several years ago, Shannon came to me asking for advice. ...About you, George nii-san."

「……何て言ってたのかな。」
"...I wonder what she could have said."

「……………紗音は嘘をつくのが下手だったからよ。譲治兄さんのことを言っているのはすぐにバレバレでさ。
".........Shannon was always really bad at lying. It was obvious pretty quickly that you were the one she was talking about.

……………自分は、
…使用人の身分だけど、親しくしてもいいのだろうか、とか。……男の人の好きそうな物は何かとか、どういう服を着たら喜ぶかとか、そんなことを色々とさ。………………なんつーのかその、まぁ妬けたぜ。」
......She...asked whether it'd be okay for her to get close to someone,

...even though she was only a servant. ...She asked about what kinds of things boys like, what kind of clothes she should wear to make them happy, lots of stuff like that. .........Hmm, well, I guess you could say I felt envious, hearing her say that."

「………それが、婚約指輪を渡されて、そこで、
……おしまいかよ。」
"......So then she was given an engagement ring,

...and it all ended right there?"

「……価値観は人それぞれだけどよ。……男から求婚されるってのは、………ある意味、
人生の到達点なんだと思うんだよ。……だからきっと。昨夜の紗音は、
心の底から、
……いや、生まれてから今までの中で、一番幸せだったと思うぜ…。」
"...Different people value things differently, ...but being proposed to by a man...

well, it can be the high point of your life. So I'm sure... Last night, I'm sure Shannon was happy...

from the bottom of her heart,

...happier than she's ever been since the day of her birth..."

「……………………………………。」
"....................."

…譲治の兄貴は顔を上げず、深い溜め息を漏らす…。
……あるいは、涙を滲ませているのか。
...George-aniki sighed deeply, without raising his head...

...Or maybe tears had risen to his eyes.

「…………紗音は昨夜、ゲストハウスの当番だったらしいんだ。……でも、…紗音は僕と一緒にゲストハウスに帰るのを恥ずかしがって、……お屋敷に行ってしまった。」
"......It seems Shannon was on duty in the guesthouse last night. ...But...because she was too embarrassed to go back to the guesthouse with me, ...she went over to the mansion."

「……紗音の気持ちを察しろよ。…婚約指輪をもらえば、どんなに予告されてたって普通は舞い上がっちまって頭は真っ白になっちまうぜ。……気恥ずかしくて仕方なかったんだろうよ。」
"...Think about how Shannon must've felt. ...When you receive an engagement ring, then no matter how much warning you've been given beforehand, it's perfectly normal to get so excited that your mind goes blank. ......She must've been incredibly embarrassed."

「……それで紗音は、
…………当番でないはずのお屋敷へ行き、…そこで郷田さんの仕事を手伝い、
……………事件に巻き込まれてしまった………。僕が、…あの日、あの場所で、……指輪なんか渡さなければ……、
紗音は、
……紗代は、
……事件に巻き込まれなかったんだ…！
"...And then, Shannon...

went to the mansion, even though she hadn't been assigned there, helped Gohda-san with his work,

and got caught up in this crime... If only I hadn't...given her that ring...on that day...in that place,

...Shannon wouldn't have...

...Sayo wouldn't have...

...been caught up in that crime...!

…ううぅうぅぅッ！！」
...Nnngaaaaaaahh!!"




「兄貴。それだけは違うぜ。断じて違う。……だから、それ以上泣くんじゃねぇ。」
「………………ぅうぅぅぅ…。」
"Aniki, that's the one place where you're wrong. It's definitely wrong. ...So don't cry anymore."

"......Aaaaaaaaaahh..."

「戦人くん。そっとしてあげなさい。」
"Battler-kun, let's leave him be."

絵羽伯母さんに言われ、俺はそれ以上、言葉をかけるのをやめる。
After Aunt Eva said that, I stopped talking to him.

…慰めの言葉は、間違えれば心を傷つける。
朱志香が兄貴の隣に座り、静かに肩を抱いていた。
...Misplaced words of comfort might actually do more harm than good.

Jessica sat down next to Aniki and put an arm around him.

………兄貴と紗音の馴れ初めからを知り、紗音から交際についての相談まで受けていたという朱志香にしか、…兄貴を慰めることはできないだろう。
Maybe only Jessica, who had known about Aniki and Shannon's love since the beginning, and who had even discussed that relationship with Shannon, ...could comfort Aniki now.

俺は、絵羽伯母さんのところへ行き、向かいのソファーに腰を下ろした…。
I went over to Aunt Eva and sat down in the opposite sofa...

「戦人くんは強いわね…。もうだいぶしっかりしているように見えるわよ。」
"Battler-kun, you really are strong... It looks like you've kept a good hold on yourself."

「…まぁその、ほら、愛の深さが傷の深さじゃないっすか。俺は別にあんなクソ親父、どう死のうが知ったことじゃないし。…霧江さんは気の毒ですが、…まぁ本当の親ってわけじゃないですしね。」
"...Umm, well, look, the depth of the love becomes the depth of the wound, right? After all, it's not like how that old bastard died has anything to do with me. ...I feel bad about Kyrie-san, but...well, she wasn't actually my parent."

「あらぁ。というわりにはさっき、すっごく大泣きしてたわよぅ？」
"My, my. If that's so, you certainly were crying a lot back then."

「まぁ、育ての親に対する恩は、あのくらい泣けばＯＫかと思いまして…。へへへ…。」
"Well, I did think at least that much crying was due as gratitude to the parent who raised me... Heheheh..."

「………その辺の切り替えの早さやドライな辺りは、本当に留弗夫譲りね。…あの子は昔から激しく喜んだり悲しんだり怒ったりしたけれど、すぐにケロリと平静を取り戻したわ。」
".........The speed of that changeover and that dry tone must've come from Rudolf. ...That kid would always get violently happy, sad, and angry, but he'd always regain his cool immediately afterwards."

「……そんなことはないっすよ。俺だって、まだまだ心のショックから立ち直れちゃいません。
"...It's nothing like that. I haven't really been able to get over the shock yet.

…ただ俺がみんなと違うのは、…それによってどういう感情が生み出されるかってことだと思います。」
...I think the only difference between me and everyone else...is the kinds of emotions it's stirred in me."

「どういうこと？」
"What do you mean?"

俺は譲治の兄貴や朱志香に比べたら、ずっと涼しそうに振舞っている。
I've been acting much calmer than George-aniki and Jessica.

…それは悲しみが浅くて、もう立ち直ったからではない。
悲しみが、別の感情に徐々にすり替わっていったからだ。
That wasn't because my sadness was any less intense, or because I'd already recovered.

My sadness was simply getting replaced gradually with a different emotion.

「…………悲しい、ってよりは、
………腹立たしいって気持ちなんすよ。どこのどいつがこんなことをしやがったのか。…横っ面に一発お見舞いしてやらないことには腹の虫が治まらねぇんです。」
"......Rather than sad,

......I'd say I'm more pissed off. What bastard did this and where? ...It's kinda been eating at me that I didn't get a chance to smack him upside the face."

それが、俺の本音だった。
このまま悲しみに暮れて膝を抱いているだけじゃ、自分を許せないのだ。
That was what I really wanted to do.

I couldn't forgive myself if I just sat there, overwhelmed with sadness and hugging my knees.

「……親父たちが殺されて以降、この島は台風に包まれたままです。……つまり、これだけの上等をキメてくれやがった野郎は、まだこの島の中にいるってことです。」
「そういうことになるわね。………今も暗い森のどこかに身を潜めているのかしら？」
"...Since the time Dad and the others were killed, this island has been covered by the typhoon. ...Which means the bastard responsible for all this is still somewhere on this island."

"Yes, that would seem to be the case. ......I wonder if they're hiding somewhere in that dark forest even now?"

………よく似た話題を、
…昨夜、ここで霧江さんとした気がする。
......I felt like I'd had...

a very similar conversation with Kyrie-san the night before.

そうだ。昨日の晩餐の席でベアトリーチェを名乗る手紙が現れて、……１９人目の人物は果たして存在するのか否か、という話をした時だ。
That's right. After the letter from the person claiming to be Beatrice appeared at the dinner table last night, ...we talked about whether or not a 19th person actually exists.

「絵羽伯母さん。………この殺人、
…昨夜のベアトリーチェの手紙と何か関連があるんでしょうかね。」
"Aunt Eva, ......do you think this murder...

has anything to do with the letter from Beatrice last night?"

「…あぁ、例の？　…………さぁ、どうかしらね。あの手紙は、お父様が遺産問題に絡みたくて出した怪文書という見方で兄弟は一致したんだけれども。………それと今朝の事件に関係があるかは、今の段階ではわかりかねるわね…。」
"...Aah, that one? ......Well, I wonder. All of the siblings agreed that the mysterious letter was sent to further complicate the problem of Father's inheritance. ......As to whether that and the case this morning are related, it's impossible to tell at this stage..."

「あの手紙、ホントにベアトリーチェなんて魔女が真里亞に渡したんすかねぇ。」
"Was that letter really given to Maria by some witch called Beatrice?"

「まっさかぁ。全部、お父様の仕組んだ茶番でしょう？　紗音ちゃん辺りに肖像画のドレスを着させて、真里亞ちゃんを騙したんでしょ？　お父様らしい、手の込みすぎた悪戯だと思うけどぉ？」
"How could it be? All of it was a farce devised by Father, wasn't it? He made Shannon-chan or someone wear the dress from the portrait and trick Maria-chan, right? Isn't that just the kind of overly intricate prank Father would pull?"

「………昨夜、霧江さんと、ベアトリーチェは実在するんだろうかって話をしたんすけど、霧江さんも俺たち１８人の中にベアトリーチェがいるだろうと言ってましたね。」
"......Last night, I talked with Kyrie-san about whether Beatrice actually exists, and Kyrie-san also said that Beatrice was probably one of the 18 of us."

「そんなの当然じゃない。この島には、私たちしかいないのよぅ？　なら私たちの中の誰かがベアトリーチェを騙ったに決まってるじゃない。」
"Isn't that obvious? There's no one else on this island besides us, right? Then there must be someone amongst us who's pretending to be Beatrice."

「この島には俺たち以外はいない、
っすか…。」
"There's no one else but us on this island,

you think...?"

「当然でしょ？　私たち以外の誰がここにいるって言うの？　この島には私たちしかいない。１８人しかいない。…なら、ベアトリーチェを騙るのも１８人の中の誰かしかいないじゃない。」
"Obviously, right? Are you saying there could be someone else here other than us? No one is on this island except us. There are only 18 people. So the one pretending to be Beatrice has to be one of those 18."

霧江さんが“チェス盤をひっくり返して”至った１９人目の否定。
Kyrie-san denied the existence of a 19th person by `spinning the chessboard around'.

絵羽伯母さんは、そこまで理論立てて至ったわけではなさそうだが、意見だけは同じようだった。
Even though Aunt Eva hadn't constructed an argument that complicated, her opinion at least was the same.

…ただ、だとすると、非常に嫌な話になる……。
...Except, if that's the case, our situation starts to look very ugly...

ベアトリーチェの手紙の時には誰かのいたずら程度で済ますことができた。
At the time of Beatrice's letter, the whole thing could be passed off as a prank set up by someone or another.

…しかし、１９人目を否定した場合、話はそれだけでは済まなくなる。
...However, if we're assuming there's no 19th person, we can't ignore this anymore.

………つまり、
......In other words...

「…１９人目がいないなら。……親父たちを殺した犯人も、１８人の中にいるってことになっちまうじゃないっすか。………つまり、今この屋敷にいる誰かが殺したってことになる…！」
"If there is no 19th person, ...then the culprit who killed Dad and the others is also one of the 18, right? ......So, in other words, the person who killed them is one of the people inside this very mansion right now...!"

「…………………………………。」
".................."

絵羽伯母さんは意味深に笑う。
Aunt Eva smiled meaningfully.

…それは伯母さんにとって、当然かつもっとも最初に気付くべき結論のようだった。
...It looked like she thought this conclusion should've been obvious from the very beginning.

「犯人は倉庫の中に６人の遺体を運び込んだわ。でも、よく倉庫の中に運び込めたわよね？　あのシャッターは常に閉められていて、施錠されていたそうよ？
"The culprit carried the bodies of those six into the storehouse. But even that was an impressive feat, don't you think? That shutter is always closed and locked, right?

つまり、倉庫内に運び込むには、シャッターの施錠を開ける必要があった。…わかる？」
In other words, in order to carry them into the storehouse, the culprit would need to unlock the shutter. ...Understand?"

「……たまたまその日、シャッターが開けっ放しになってた可能性は？」
"...Is it possible the shutter was left open by mistake that day?"

「使用人たちは常に閉めていると言ってたわ。つまり、鍵を使用人室から持ち出さなくては、倉庫は絶対に開けられない。」
"The servants said it's always kept locked. In other words, unless the culprit took the keys from the servant room, there's no way they could've opened the storehouse."

「鍵は使用人室の１つしかないんすかね…。」
"I wonder if the key in the servant room was the only one..."

「源次さんはそうだと言ってるわ。ということは、犯人はそのたった１つの倉庫の鍵の在り処を知っていて持ち出した。
"Genji-san said that was the case. Which means the culprit knew where that single key was kept and took it.

さっき、嘉音くんが使用人室に鍵を戻すところを見たわ。壁にびっしりと鍵が掛けられていて、とても素人にはどこに何が掛けてあるのかわからなかった。犯人は、その中から倉庫の鍵を見事選び出したのよ？
Just now, I watched when Kanon-kun returned the key to the servant room. The wall was packed with keys, and I don't think a novice would know where or what those keys went to. The culprit was miraculously able to find the storehouse key among all of those."

しかも、札も何も付いていない鍵を手にして、薔薇庭園裏にある倉庫の鍵だと理解した。…ついでに言うと、倉庫の場所すら理解していた。………もっとはっきり断言するわ。犯人は使用人室の内部にも熟知している。」
"Furthermore, even though the key didn't have a tag or anything sticking to it, they knew it was the key to the storehouse behind the rose garden. ...And that means they also knew where the storehouse was. ......I'll say it even clearer. The culprit knew the inside of the servant room well."

それは非常に単純明快な話だった。
Her argument was extremely plain and clear.

……遺体が薔薇庭園のどこかの茂みにでも放り込まれていたなら、まだ理解は容易だった。
...If the bodies had been found thrown somewhere in the bushes of the rose garden, there wouldn't have been much to go on.

しかし、たった１つしかない倉庫の鍵は使用人室にあり、しかも大量の鍵と一緒にしまわれており、素人目にはとても判別できない。
However, if there was only one key to the storehouse in the servant room, and it was stored with such a large group of keys, a novice would not be able to tell them apart.

となると、普段、使用人室に出入りしていて、鍵の所在などについて熟知している人間が犯人ということになる。
This meant the culprit was someone who went into the servant room a lot and was familiar with the locations of the keys.

…使用人室には普通、家人だって入らない。
……ということは…………、
...The family members didn't normally go into the servant room.

...Which meant that.........

「………ってことは、
………使用人の誰かが、
……犯人………。」
「悪いけど、それ以上は伯母さんも言えないわよ。……でも、ひとつだけ教えられることがあるわ。」
「……何すか。」
"......Which means that...

...one of the servants is...

...the culprit......"

"I'm sorry, but even I can't tell you any more than that. ...However, I'll tell you one thing."

"...What's that?"

「犯人、……うぅん、犯人たちは複数で、そして充分な武装をしていたと考えられるわ。だってそうでしょう？　食堂にいた兄さんたち４人を一度に襲って殺し、合計６人分の遺体を、遥々と薔薇庭園の向こうの倉庫まで運んで、悪趣味な化粧と落書きを施してる。……これだけのことを単独犯で行えるはずもないでしょう？」
"It's reasonable to think that the culprit...no, culprits...are multiple in number and fairly well armed. They'd have to be, wouldn't they? They had to assault the four in the dining hall and kill them, drag a total of six bodies all the way to the storehouse beyond the rose garden, and arrange for that disgusting makeup and the graffiti on the shutter. ......There's no way that a single culprit could carry out all of that on their own, right?"

道理だ。時間さえ掛ければ１人でも不可能ではないだろうが、それではあまりにも手間が掛かる。
It made sense. It probably would've been possible for a single person with enough time, but it would take so incredibly long.

少なくない人数が関わったと考えるのが妥当だろう。
It was probably safe to assume that a significant number of people were involved.

「……………ひゅぅ。ってことは絵羽伯母さんは、
……、
使用人の人たちがみんなグルだろうって言ってんすか。」
"......Whew. So what you're saying...

...

is that maybe all of the servants were in cahoots."




「静かになさいな？　憶測で言っちゃ悪いわよ。
"Please keep it quiet, okay? It wouldn't be right to voice mere speculation like this.

……それに、もし本当にそうだったらどうするつもり？　彼らは私たちを生かして帰さないでしょうねぇ。しかも、兄さんたち４人をやすやすと殺した相手なのよ。
...And if it really is true, what would you do next? They might not let us leave here alive. This is an opponent who had no trouble killing Nii-san and the three others.

今、この部屋に残っていて、まともに戦えそうな人間は、うちの家族の３人にせいぜい戦人くんで４人ってところ？　状況は昨晩と何も変わらない。……つまり、犯人にとって、残る私たちを皆殺しにするなんて簡単なことなのよ。」
Right now, the only ones I can count on to fight with me are the three in my family and maybe you, which comes to a total of four people, right? We're no better off than they were last night. ...In short, it'd be easy for the culprits to massacre the rest of us."

俺は、親父たちを殺した犯人を、警察よりも早く暴きたいと思い、こうして絵羽伯母さんと推理ごっこをしていた。
I'd been playing detective with Aunt Eva, trying to expose the person who had killed Dad and the rest before the police did.

…もし見事犯人を看破できたなら、その証拠を突きつけたかった。
……そうすれば、よくある探偵映画みたいに、犯人は観念して降参すると思い込んできた。
...If only I could cleverly penetrate the culprit's identity and stick the proof in their face.

......I'd been so sure that, just like in one of those detective movies, the culprit would then give up and surrender.

しかし、犯人が降参するのは、抗っても無駄だからという前提があるからだ。
However, the culprit would only surrender if there was no way for them to fight back.

今この島で起こっている事件の犯人たちは、無力どころか、島に残った人間全員を皆殺しにすることすら可能かもしれない。
The culprits behind the crime on this island were far from helpless...and might even be able to massacre all of the remaining people here.

…しかもこの島は台風によって切り取られた巨大な密室で、殺す時間も、そして何かの工作や偽装をする時間も、明日までたっぷり丸一日ある……。
...And on top of that, this island was like a giant closed room, cut off from the outside world by the typhoon, so they had a full day, until tomorrow, to kill, scheme and camouflage themselves...

つまり、今の俺たちはまだ推理ごっこに興じられるような安全圏にはいない…。
In short, it wasn't a safe atmosphere where we could get very far by playing detective...

それどころか、犯人たちが機嫌を損ね、再び大量殺人を繰り返すかもしれない恐怖に怯えていなければならない段階なのだ…。
To the contrary, we were at a stage where we had to be scared stiff, since playing detective might displease the culprits...and cause them to commit another mass murder...

「…まぁ、あくまでも可能性の問題よぅ？　……でも私は、使用人の人たちをまだ信用できないわね。それに、私は使用人だけを疑ってるわけじゃないわ。さらに黒幕がいるかもしれないと思ってるわよ？」
"...Well, it is just a possibility, right? ...But I can't bring myself to trust the servants yet. And that doesn't mean I only suspect them. Don't you think there might be some mastermind behind all this?"

「黒幕？　ほぅ…、どうしてっすか。」
"A mastermind? Hmm, ...why do you say that?"

「勘よぅ。……使用人は書いて字の如し。誰かに使用されて手足となる存在よ？
"It's just a feeling. ...Think about what the word servant literally means. It means someone who serves as someone else's arms and legs, right?

殺されたのは右代宮家の親族ばかり。なら、その結果で利害が発生する人間が関わるのは当然。」
It was a bunch of Ushiromiya family members who got killed. So naturally, there must be someone involved who stands to gain from that result."

これまた単純明快…。
This was also plain and clear...

右代宮家では今まさに、祖父さまが死んだら遺産の分配はどうするかなんて話の真っ最中だ。
The Ushiromiya family had been right in the middle of discussions about how to distribute the inheritance when Grandfather died.

古典の推理小説で使い古された典型的な設定なら、これは間違いなく遺産問題に絡む右代宮家縁者の犯罪…。
If this case followed the standard form of any classic mystery novel, the crime was definitely caused by someone with ties to the Ushiromiya family and who was involved in the inheritance problem...

多分、伯母さんもその辺りの小説をいくつか読んだことがあるのだろう。
Aunt Eva had probably read a few books in that genre herself.

……絵羽伯母さんの理論は、やや決めつけっぽいところはありながらも、誰もが至る考えである王道的なものだ。
...Her argument may have had a few blind assumptions in it, but it was a standard conclusion that anyone might've reached.

恐らく、至る筋道は違っても、最終的にはほとんどの人間が使用人たちを疑うことになるだろう。
I think most people would end up suspecting the servants, even if they used different reasoning to get there.

特に、シャッターの鍵を巡る話は、使用人の誰かが事件に関わっていることを濃厚かつ容易に疑わせる…。
Especially the story about the key to the shutter. That made it very easy to suspect that one of the servants was involved...

「…………………だぁから、
…なぜか気に入らねぇんすよねぇ。」
"............And that's why...

I don't like it."




「気に入らないって、何の話ぃ？」
"What do you mean, you don't like it?"

「いえいえ、こっちの話っす。いっひっひ！」
"Nah, just talking to myself. Ihihi!"

俺はおどけながら誤魔化すが、自分の中の違和感をどうしても拭えなかった。
I tried to dodge her question by joking, but I couldn't erase the sense of unease welling up inside me.

……あまりにも至る推理が安易だからだ。
...After all, her conclusion was such an easy one to reach.

~ib~誰でも至れる推理~ib~。
~ib~A conclusion that anyone could reach~ib~.

…それがどうしても納得できねぇ。
...And I just couldn't be satisfied with that.

…霧江さんに習った“チェス盤をひっくり返して”の考え方だと、……だからこそ、使用人が犯人ということはありえないと思うのだ。
...If I tried `spinning the chessboard around' like I'd learned from Kyrie-san, ...this was exactly why a servant couldn't possibly be the culprit.

本当に使用人たちが犯人なら、自分たちの縁のある場所には遺体を隠さない。
自分たちが鍵を管理する薔薇庭園の倉庫などもってのほかだ。
If the servants really were the culprits, they wouldn't hide the bodies in a place connected to themselves.

Why on earth would they use the rose garden shed if they were the ones in charge of the key that could unlock it?

警察は真っ先に鍵の管理方法などで追求してくるだろう。
The police would probably immediately pursue whoever had been in control of the key.

そこから何かが露呈する危険もある。
……彼らが犯人であると仮定すればするほど、倉庫に遺体を移す理由がない。
It was even possible that some other facts might come to light as a result.

...The more we think of the servants as the culprits, the less reason they had to carry the bodies into the storehouse.

…というのを逆手にとって、わざと倉庫に置いたのか？
いや、それだけは断じてありえない。
...But what if they knew we'd think that, and put the corpses in the storehouse for that very reason?

No, that's completely impossible.

警察が来て現場検証を行えば、様々なことが判明するだろう。
犯人たちがどんなに注意深く殺人を実行しようとも、必ず何かの痕跡を発見される。
When the police come and inspect the scene of the crime, they'll probably be able to uncover many things.

No matter how carefully the culprits carried out that murder, some traces will definitely be found.

つまり、彼らにとって百害はあっても一利はないのだ。
In other words, they had everything to lose and nothing to gain.

こうして考えると、犯人サイドからこの殺人ゲームを見た場合、遺体をアピールすることに意味が感じられない。
If you think about it this way and look at this murder game from the culprit's side, it's hard to imagine why they'd want to call attention to the corpses.

遺体が見付かれば、警察への通報とか、残った人間たちが用心深くなるとか、犯人探しを始めるとか、…とにかく犯人にとって居心地のよくなることは何一つ起こらない。
Once the corpses were found, it could result in someone sending a report to the police, or it might make the remaining people more cautious, or it might make the survivors start to search for the culprit. None of these things would make life any easier for the culprit.

…最近読んだ『ひぐらしのなく頃に』とかいう小説でも主人公の母親が言ってたぜ。
...It's just like the words of the main character's mother in a novel I read recently, called `Higurashi No Naku Koro Ni'.

完全犯罪ってのは、“起承転結の「起」”を起こさないことが肝要だと。
Every story needs to have a beginning, a middle, and an end. Eliminating that `beginning' is essential for the perfect crime.

……今、祖父さまの姿が見えない。
...Right now, we don't know where Grandfather is.

すでに犠牲になっているのか、あるいは犯人の１人なのかはわからないが、………このわからない状態の方が、犯人にとっては好都合のはず。
We don't know if he's already become a victim or if he's one of the culprits, ......but this state of confusion must be beneficial to the killer.

遺体をこれ見よがしにアピールして、殺人事件がさぁ起こりましたよなんて宣伝するのは、まったく犯人にとって得るものがない。
The culprit has absolutely nothing to gain by showing us the bodies in such a obvious way and making us all realize there's been a murder.

いや、そこでこそ“チェス盤をひっくり返す”ところさ。
In fact, this is the perfect place to `spin the chessboard around'.

なら、このこれ見よがしなアピールは犯人の目的そのものってことになる。
In other words, showing us the corpses in such a flashy way must be the culprit's goal in and of itself.

……つまり犯人にとっては下手すると、~ib~殺すことよりも、あそこに６人の死体を用意する~ib~
...So, at the very least, to the culprit,

~ib~the appearance of six corpses there meant ~ib~

~ib~方が意味があったってことになる~ib~。
~ib~more than the deaths themselves~ib~.

つまり、犯人はこの殺人を誇示しているわけだ。
誰に？
In other words, the culprit wanted this murder on display.

To whom?

……俺たちにだ。
こいつはメッセージだ。
犯人たちは俺たちに、何かを突きつけている。
...To us.

This is a message.

The culprit's trying to shove something in our faces.

…それが何か、わからない。
...I don't know what it is.

現時点では、この趣味の悪い大量殺人は、俺たち全員への悪意以上のものは感じ取れない。
At this point in time, this vulgar mass murder isn't making me feel anything except a malice directed towards all of us.

　……全員への、
悪意、
…か。
...Malice towards...

all of us,

...is it?




殺された６人は、今、生き残っている人たち全員にとって、みんな何らかのつながりがある。
Each one of the survivors has some kind of connection to one of the six victims.

蔵臼伯父さんの死は、朱志香の一家に悲しみを与えた。
Uncle Krauss's death brought Jessica the grief of losing a family member.

俺の親父と霧江さんの死は、俺に悲しみを与え、楼座叔母さんの死は真里亞に悲しみを与えた。
The deaths of Dad and Kyrie-san brought me sorrow, while Aunt Rosa's death brought Maria sorrow.

……郷田さんの死は使用人仲間に衝撃を与えただろうし、紗音ちゃんの死は、婚約した譲治の兄貴や、姉と慕っていた嘉音くんに悲しみを与えた。
......Gohda-san's death probably shocked his fellow servants, and Shannon-chan's death brought grief both to George-aniki, who had proposed to her, and Kanon-kun, who had loved her like an older sister.

……今この島にいる誰もに、均等に悲しみを与えているのだ。
......Everyone now on this island has received an equal amount of sadness.

絵羽伯母さんは、使用人たちがグルに違いないと言い切ったが、……なら郷田さんや紗音ちゃんの遺体はどう説明するのか。
Aunt Eva was sure that the servants were in cahoots, ...but then, how could you explain the deaths of Gohda-san and Shannon-chan?

……それにこの論法で行けば、~ib~この６人の~ib~
...At any rate, by this argument, ~ib~the grief caused by the six deaths hit ~ib~

~ib~死によって全員に与えられている悲しみが、絵羽伯母さんと秀吉伯父さんだけは免れている~ib~。
~ib~everyone but Aunt Eva and Uncle Hideyoshi~ib~.

使用人たちに疑いを向け、蚊帳の外を気取る絵羽伯母さん自身、疑いの余地がないとは言い切れないのだ。
Even Aunt Eva, who had directed suspicion at the servants and acted as though she herself was beyond suspicion, could not be ruled out as a suspect.

……そもそも、シャッターの鍵の話で煙に撒かれたから使用人が疑わしいという論法になってしまったが、……この殺人で誰が得をするのかという、動機の線から疑うと、…………絵羽伯母さんはもっとも怪しい人物に浮上する。
...In the first place, she was able to argue that the servants were suspicious by focusing on the shutter's key, ...but if you look at it from a perspective of motive and who would gain, ......Aunt Eva's name rises to the top of the list.

「……戦人くんが何を考えてるか、伯母さんわかるわよぅ？」
"...I know what you're thinking, Battler-kun."

「え？　いっひっひ、嫌だなぁ、
内緒にしててくださいよぅ、
卑猥なことで頭をいっぱいにしてたなんてぇ。」
"Huh? Ihihi, oh no,

please don't tell anybody...

about how my head's so full of obscene stuff."

「私が、この殺人で一番得をする。……どうせ疑われるだろうから、先に自己申告しておくわ。」
"I'm the one who's going to gain the most from these murders. ...Since I'm going to be suspected anyway, I might as well get it out in the open."

茶化して誤魔化したつもりだったが、通用しないようだった。
I tried to dodge the issue by joking around, but apparently it didn't work.

「遺産は兄弟の数で分割する。でも今や、４兄弟は私ひとり。右代宮家の全財産は全て私のものになるの。……うふふふふふ。」
"The inheritance will be divided into as many parts as there are siblings. But right now, I'm the only one of the four left. All of the assets of the Ushiromiya family will become mine. ...Heheheheheh."

「秀吉伯父さんが聞いたら、よさんか絵羽、洒落にならんって言うところっすね…。」
"If Uncle Hideyoshi heard you, he'd say `Could you give it a rest, it's not funny'..."

「ごめんねぇ？　どう取り繕ったってどうせ疑われるだろうから、ふざけただけよ。
"I'm sorry. I was just fooling around, since I'm going to be suspected anyway no matter how much I try to smooth it over.

……だからこの殺人は、私の立場から見れば、私を疑わせるためのものではないかと思ってるの。……困ったことに、昨夜のアリバイは弱いわ。」
...That's why, from my point of view, this murder might've been designed to cast suspicion on me. ...Unfortunately, my alibi for last night is weak."

「聞かせてもらってもいいっすか。昨夜のことを。」
"Could you tell me a bit more about last night?"

「戦人くんたちも知っている通り、兄弟が遺産をどう食い千切り合うかという話し合いは、深夜まで続いたわ。でも、何時まで続いたかは知らない。私と主人は朝が早かったからね。もう眠くて眠くて、２４時を過ぎた辺りで抜けさせてもらったの。そしてゲストハウスに戻って休んだわ。」
"As you know, the discussion between the siblings of how to slice up and eat the inheritance continued until late in the night. But I don't know how late it lasted. My husband and I had woken up early that morning. We were so sleepy, and a little past midnight, they let us go. We then returned to the guesthouse and rested there."

「……それを、秀吉伯父さん以外の誰かに証明できるっすか？　いやいや、別に絵羽伯母さんを疑ってるわけじゃないっすよ〜？　ひっひっひ！」
"...Can anyone other than Uncle Hideyoshi prove that? No, wait, it's not like I suspect you or anything, okay? Hihihi!"

「あら、どうだか？　くすくす。証明になるかわからないけれど、ゲストハウスに戻ってきた時、源次さんに出迎えを受けてタオルはいるかと聞かれたわ。
"Oh, are you sure about that? *giggle* I don't know if it counts as proof, but when we returned to the guesthouse, we were greeted by Genji-san, who asked if we needed a towel.

だから私たちがゲストハウスに戻ってきた時間は２４時過ぎだと証明してくれると思うわよ。……もっとも、私の仮説通り、使用人たちもグルなのだとしたら、こんなのアリバイにならないけどねぇ？」
I think that should be enough to prove we returned to the guesthouse a little after midnight. ...Though, if my theory was correct, the servants would all be in cahoots, and that wouldn't actually make for much of an alibi."

「確かにそうっすねぇ？　ってことは俺、今、真犯人と推理ごっこをしてるってことになるんすか？　いっひっひ！」
"Hey, you've got a point there. Guess that means I'm playing detective with the real culprit right now, huh? Ihihi!"

「でも、私の名誉のために言わせてもらうけど、遺産目当てだったなら、こんな変な殺人はしないわよぅ？
"However, let me say this for my honor's sake: if I was after the inheritance, I'd never commit such a bizarre set of murders.

だって、遺産相続権を喪失させるだけなら、どんな死に方だって構わない。むしろ事故死に見せかけた方がスマートでしょう？　使用人たちを抱きこんで、周到に計画していたなら、なおさらそうするでしょうよ。」
After all, if I just wanted to make them forfeit their rights to the inheritance, it wouldn't matter to me how they died. It'd be much smarter of me to try and make their deaths look like accidents. Especially if you're assuming I laid out some careful plan that involved even the servants."

「確かにそうっすね…。営利で人を殺すなら、それは常に殺人に見せるべきではない。」
"You've got a point there... If you're killing someone for personal gain, you definitely shouldn't make it look like a murder."

「そういうことよ？　だから伯母さんは、今からとてもブルーな気持ちなわけ。……警察には黒幕扱いされて、さんざん調べられるでしょうねぇ。やだやだ…。」
"Exactly. That's why I'm in such a blue mood. ...The police will probably treat me like the mastermind and investigate all kinds of things. Not fun at all..."

絵羽伯母さんは、肩をすくめて苦笑いして見せた。
Aunt Eva shrugged with a bitter smile.

……使用人たちが疑わしく思えるのが容易なように、絵羽伯母さんを疑わしく思うのもとても容易だ。
It was just as easy to suspect Aunt Eva as it was to suspect the servants.

なら“チェス盤をひっくり返したら”、……容易に疑えてしまう絵羽伯母さんでもありえないのか…？
So if we `spin the chessboard around', ...does that make it impossible for the culprit to be her, suspicious as she is...?

しかし、その論法がまかり通るなら、動機なんて何の役にも立たなくなってしまう。
However, if that sort of argument always works, then motive can never help us in any way.

いや、そんなことはないはず…。
動機を知ることは犯人を知る強力な手掛かりになるはずだ。
No, that can't be right...

Knowing the motive must give us powerful clues towards knowing the culprit.

…だから古今の殺人者たちは、巧みにそれを気取られないよう、事件を複雑に偽装するのではないか……。
...That's why murderers from all time periods disguise crimes in complicated ways, cleverly preventing their motives from being discovered...

………わからない、…わからない…。
チェス盤をひっくり返す度に、表と裏が何度も行ったり来たり…。
......I don't get it. ...I just don't get it...

Every time I spin the chessboard around, it keeps flipping from front to back and back to front...

…俺の思考は真相に近付いているのか。
……それとも………。
...Are my thoughts bringing me closer to the truth?

...Or are they......

絵羽伯母さんは、それ以上の会話を望まなかったので、俺は腕を組みながら窓辺へ行き、少し頭を冷やした。
Aunt Eva didn't want to talk any more than that, so I folded my arms and headed to the window to cool my head a little.

客間を見渡してみると、譲治の兄貴たちも集まって話をしていた。
…どうも、例のシャッターに描かれていたとかいう魔法陣の話らしい。
As I looked over the parlor, I saw George-aniki and the others gathered, talking.

...It looked like they were talking about the magic circle that had been painted onto the shutter.

秀吉伯父さんは、それを思い出しながら、真里亞のノートの余白にそれを書き出している。
As Uncle Hideyoshi thought back to that time, he started drawing the shape in the margins of Maria's notebook.

……なるほど、祖父さまの次にオカルトに詳しい真里亞には、その意味がわかるかもしれない。
...I see, since Maria was second only to Grandfather in knowledge of the occult, she might understand what it meant.

「うーん、多分こんな感じだったと思うで！　十字架をアレンジしたみたいなマークが描かれとったんや。
"Hmmm, I think it was probably somethin' like that! There was a mark that looked like a variation of a cross.

そして、こんな感じで外周の円を取り囲むように妙な文字がびっしり書き込まれていて、十字架の上下左右の辺と、その四隅にも何か書かれていたんや。アルファベットとかそういうのとちゃうで。あれはよく言う古代文字とかいうやつや。」
And then, surroundin' the circle all around the perimeter were these closely packed strange letters on all four sides of the cross, and in the four corners, there was somethin' written. It didn't look like the alphabet or somethin' like that. It was what they call ancient characters."

「……あと、円周部の頂点に小さなマークがありましたな。…小さな丸を５つ、十字状に並べ、それぞれを直線で結んだようなマークでした…。」
"...And, around the top of the circumference, there was a small mark. ...Five small circles arranged in a + sign, and straight lines connecting them..."

「あぁ、確かにそんなのも描いてあったで…！　うん、図形的には間違いなくこれや。細かい文字はわからんが、配列はほぼ同じや。」
"Ah, yeah, there definitely was somethin' like that drawn there...! Yep, there's no mistakin' the shape. I don't understand the thin characters, but the arrangement was nearly the same."

その図形をみんなが覗き込むので、俺も覗き込んでみた。
Everyone was staring down at the shape, so I stared down at it too.

…聞く話では、こいつがあの倉庫のシャッターに、血みたいな塗料か何かでべったり描かれていたらしい。
...From what I'd heard, this had been painted on the shutter to the storehouse with some material that looked like blood.

……なるほど、こいつは不気味だな。
...I see, this sure is unsettling.

「…こんなわけのわかんねぇもんを描きたがるのは、祖父さまだけだろ。……まったく、どこに行っちまったんだ？！　とっ捕まえて、意味を聞き出してやりたいぜ！！」
"...Grandfather's probably the only one who'd wanna draw something this weird. ...Seriously, where did he go?! I wanna grab him and ask what the hell this is supposed to mean!!"

朱志香の声には短気な怒りが含まれている。
Jessica's voice contained impatience and anger.

祖父さまが犯人だとまでは言わないが、祖父さまが犯人の素性を知っているに違いないと考えているようだった。
She hadn't gone so far as to say Grandfather was the culprit, but she seemed sure that Grandfather knew something about the culprit's background.

……確かに、右代宮家とオカルトの２つを結びつけたら、十人が十人、うちの祖父さまを名指しするだろう。
......Of course, if you were searching for a link connecting the Ushiromiya family to the occult, ten out of ten people would think of Grandfather.

……そして、オカルトの知識がない人間には、この妙なマークの意味はわからない。
......Also, to a person who knew nothing of the occult, this strange mark would have no meaning.

ってことは、………、こいつは、…祖父さまに宛てたものじゃねぇんだろうか……。
Which meant that, ......this might have been...something addressed to Grandfather...

そうさ、犯行をアピールするのはそれを生き残った者たちに見せ付けたいからだ。
That's right, and the reason the crime was shown to the survivors was so they'd find this.

……じゃあ、メッセージの相手の、肝心の祖父さまはどこに消えちまったんだ……？
...In that case, where had Grandfather, the essential recipient of this message, disappeared off to...?

「こんな図形に、何か心当たりはあるかい…？」
"Does this shape ring any bells...?"

「…………………………。……うー。」
真里亞は真剣な顔をして図形に見入っている。
".....................Uu-."

Maria looked at the shape with a serious face.

…得意分野とあって張り切っているのだろうか。
...Maybe she was enthusiastic because this was her area of expertise.

…だが、その様子はどこか他人事で、…自分の母の遺体を閉じ込めていたシャッターに描かれていたもの、という風には見えなかった…。
...However, her appearance was that of someone separated from the events at hand, ...as though this thing hadn't been drawn on the shutter closed around her mother's corpse...

「…僕の第一印象では、ドイツの十字章に似たデザインだなって思ったかな…。」
"...My first impression was that the design resembled a German Cross..."

「あー…。確かにこんなデザインや。ということはドイツと何か関係があるんか。」
"Aah... It certainly does have that kind of design. Does that mean it has somethin' to do with Germany?"

「ドイツの十字章はもともと、聖地巡礼者を守るための騎士修道士たちの紋章だったそうですな…。」
"The German Cross was originally a crest from a religious order of knights and was supposed to protect pilgrims traveling to sacred places..."

「……つまり、この魔法陣には、宗教的な意味があるってことかよ…？　ますますにちんぷんかんぷんだぜ……。」
"...So in other words, this magic circle might have some religious meaning...? This is starting to sound like gibberish..."

俺もその議論に加わろうと全体を見渡した時、……ぎょっとする。
When I looked over at all of them, preparing to jump into the discussion, ...something shocked me.

真里亞が、…何とも形容できない不気味な表情で笑っていたからだ。
Maria was smiling, ...an eerie and incomprehensible expression on her face.

…それはまるで、議論し合うみんなの無知さ加減を馬鹿にするような、そんな笑い。……真里亞が浮かべられるなんて、夢にも思わなかった表情だった…。
...It was almost as if she was making fun of everyone's ignorance. ...It was an expression I wouldn't have dreamed to find on Maria's face...

そして、
……笑う。
And,

...she laughed.

その不気味な、軋むような笑い声を、
…俺は目の前で見ているにもかかわらず、断じて認めたくなかった。
That eerie, jarring laugh...

was something I didn't want to believe was possible, even though I was looking at it right in front of my eyes.

「きひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひ。全然違うよ、みんな。きっひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひ…。こんなの見てわっかんないかなぁ。きっひひひひひひひひひ。」
"Kihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihi. You people aren't even close. Kihhihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihi... Can't you tell just by looking? Kihhihihihihihihihihi."

誰もが度肝を抜かれている間、真里亞はひとり、機嫌良さそうにけたけたと笑い続けていた…。
While everyone was busy being scared out of their wits, Maria kept on cackling happily by herself...

やがて、その笑いは唐突にぷっつり途切れる。
でも表情は、真里亞とは到底思えない誰かのままだった。
After a while, that laugh was suddenly and abruptly cut off.

But her expression still looked like it belonged to someone completely different from Maria.

「これは太陽の７の魔法陣だよ。……書かれてる文字はヘブライ語。貸して？」
"This is the seventh magic circle of the sun. ...The characters are written in Hebrew. Give it here."

「あ、……あぁ。」
"Ah, ...sure."

呆気に取られる秀吉の手から真里亞は筆記用具を奪う。
Maria stole the writing materials from the stunned Hideyoshi's hand.

そして、秀吉の描いた魔法陣の隣に、さらさらと魔法陣を描き込んでいく…。
She then started drawing another magic circle with a rustle, right next to the one Hideyoshi had drawn...

「……ね？　こんな図形だったんじゃないかな？」
"...See? It looked sort of like this, right?"

「ぅ……、うむ…。そんな図形だった…。」
"Y-Yes... It was..."

「…ま、真里亞、すごいな…。さっすが詳しいぜ…。」
"...M-Maria, incredible... You really do know a lot..."

朱志香が取り繕うように褒め言葉を口にする。
Jessica tried to smooth things over by praising Maria.

……みんなのよく知る真里亞であることを確かめたかったのかもしれない。
Maybe she wanted to confirm that this was still the Maria we all knew so well.

…でも真里亞は特に返事を返してはくれなかった。
...But Maria didn't answer her in any way in particular.

真里亞は、図形の隙間に見慣れない文字をさらさらと書き込んでいく。
Maria began swiftly writing unfamiliar characters in the corners of the shape.

…それを見る秀吉伯父さんと南條先生の目がみるみる見開かれていく…。
...When Uncle Hideyoshi and Doctor Nanjo saw them, their eyes immediately began to open wide...

「天地と左右に書かれているのは風火水土を司る天使たちの名。
"Written on the top and bottom and left and right are the names of the angels who preside over wind, fire, earth and water.

Chasan, Arel, Phorlakh, and Taliahad.

$Free1そして斜め四方には四大の王たちの名。
And in the four corners are the names of the four great kings.

Ariel, Seraph, Tharshis, and Cherub.

$Free1…合ってる？」
...Is that what you saw?"

見たものを正確に書くことはできなくても…、見たものと同じものをもう一度見せられたなら、それだと断言することは難しくない。
Even if they hadn't been able to correctly write what they'd seen, ...when they were once again shown something identical, it wasn't difficult for them to realize the two were the same.

真里亞に合っているかと聞かれ、秀吉伯父さんと南條先生はうんうんと何度も頷く。
When Maria asked them whether it matched, Uncle Hideyoshi and Doctor Nanjo nodded over and over again.

「間違いない…、そうや、確かにこんな文字が書かれとった…！　何でこんなん書けるんや……。」
"There's no mistake, that's it. I'm sure there were characters that looked like that...! How were you able to write somethin' like that...?"

「あ、…あと、円周部にも文字が書かれておりましたな……。」
"Th-There were also characters written around the circumference..."

「わかってるよ。……………………………こうでしょ？」
真里亞はさらさらと円周部にもヘブライ語をぐるりと書き込んで行く…。
"I know. .........Like this, right?"

Maria quickly began to surround the circumference with more Hebrew writing...

「旧約聖書の詩篇、第１１６編の１６節と１７節だよ。……聖書くらい、読んでなきゃ。きひひひひひひひ……。」
"It's from Psalms of the Old Testament, the 16th and 17th verses of the 116th Psalm. ...You must've at least read the Bible, right? Kihihihihihihihi..."

知っていることがさも当り前であるかのように、真里亞は笑う。
Acting as though knowing this was only common sense, Maria laughed.

しばらくの間、俺も含め全員が絶句するしかなかった。
…やがて譲治の兄貴が我に帰り、ようやく言葉を口にできた。
For a while, everyone, including me, was at a loss for words.

...A little later, George-aniki returned to his senses and slowly managed to speak.

「……すごいね、驚いたよ…。…それで、この魔法陣にはどんな意味があるんだい？」
"...That's incredible. I'm surprised... ...So, what meaning does this magic circle have?"

「太陽の力を借りる魔法陣だよ。……黄金で描き護符にして身につけたる者は、いかなる牢獄であろうとも束縛から逃れ、自由を得られる力を授けられる。」
"It's a magic circle to borrow the power of the sun. ......He who wears it as a talisman drawn in gold shall be able to break free from the bonds of any prison and receive the power to gain freedom."

「…束縛から逃れ、
……自由を得られる…？　意味深だぜ…。」
"...To break free from bonds...

...and gain freedom...? It sounds deep..."

「この束縛という意味は、何も肉体的なものだけを指さないと解釈されている。…だから、縛られて牢屋にいる人ばかりに意味があるわけじゃないよ。しがらみや逃れ得ぬ運命など、精神的な束縛からの解放も意味してるんだよ。」
"The word `bonds' is not limited in its interpretation to some kind of physical object. ...Therefore, it does not only hold meaning for people locked up in an actual jail. It can also refer to the release from mental bonds such as ties of obligation and inescapable fate."

「……しがらみや、
逃れ得ぬ運命、……か。…これまた意味深だな。」
"...Ties of obligation and...

inescapable fate, ...you say? ...That's also pretty deep."

「しかしさっぱりわからん…。それとあの６人の遺体とどんな関係があるっちゅうんや。…束縛からの解放どころか、殺された上に倉庫に閉じ込められてたんやで？！」
"But I really don't understand... What does this have to do with those six bodies? ...Far from bein' released, they were killed and stuffed in a storehouse, weren't they?!"

「別にその６人のために魔法陣が描かれてるわけじゃないね。魔法陣のために、６人はそこにいるんでしょ。お気の毒だよ。
"It's not like the magic circle was drawn for their sakes. The six of them were there for the sake of the magic circle. It is truly pitiable.

…きひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひひ。」
...Kihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihihi."

「どういう意味だい…？　魔法陣のために、６人がいるってのは一体？」
"What do you mean...? What in the world do you mean when you say the six of them were there for the sake of the magic circle?"

真里亞は、人差し指を立てて、小馬鹿にするような仕草で振ってみせる。
Maria lifted up her pointer finger and waggled it as if she were making fun of us.

「それは円周部に書いてるよ。読めないかなぁ？　詩篇、第１１６編、１６節と１７節。
"That's written around the circumference. Can't you read it? Psalms, chapter 116, verses 16 and 17.

……読んであげるよ。“主は私の枷を解かれました。私はあなたに感謝の生贄を捧げ、主の御名を呼ぶでしょう”。……ね？」
...I'll read it for you. `The Lord has freed me from my chains. I will offer to you the sacrifice of thanksgiving, and will call on the name of the Lord.' ......See?"

「ね、って…、
………何を言ってるのかさっぱりだぜ。」
"See, you say...

......I've got no idea what you're talking about."

「…………生贄だ、
……ってのか？」
"......You're saying...

they're human sacrifices?"




今、真里亞が読み上げた部分が魔法陣の肝要な部分なのだとしたら、……この魔法陣はご利益の代償として生贄を捧げると言っている。
If what Maria had just read aloud was a vital part of the magic circle, ...then it was saying that sacrifices had to be offered in order for this magic circle to be effective.

…そして、この魔法陣が描かれた倉庫の中には生贄が捧げられていた………。
...So, human sacrifices had been offered inside the storehouse, where the magic circle had been drawn......

同じ想像には、やや遅れて全員が至ったらしい。
A heartbeat later, everyone else seemed to reach the same conclusion.

…ある者は呆然とし、ある者は狂っていると吐き捨てながら拳を膝に打ち付ける…。
...Some people were shocked, and others spat out that this was insane as they punched their knees...

……何とも薄気味悪い話になってきやがった。
…しかも納得できねぇし理解もできねぇ。
...This was starting to get incredibly disturbing.

...And we couldn't accept it or understand it.

……どんな魔法陣だろうとお呪いだろうと、信じてるヤツが勝手にやればいいさ、イチャモンなんか付けねぇさ。
...I don't care what kind of magic circles or curses other people believe in, I won't pick a fight with them.

…でもよ、そんな下らねぇことの生贄に親父たちは殺されたのかよ……！
何とも遣り切れない気持ちだった。
...But did they really kill Dad and the rest as sacrifices for crap like that...?!

I just couldn't stand that feeling.

……これならまだしも、遺産が絡んでどうのこうのって話でうんざりしてた方がマシだってもんだ…！
...Compared to this, I preferred it when we were still disgusted by that theory about the fight over the inheritance...!

俺は怒りとも悲しみともつかない感情に苛立ちながら、みんなの輪を抜け、再び窓辺に戻った。
As I started getting pissed off with a feeling between anger and sadness, I broke from the circle everyone was in and returned once again to the window.

……昨日から何かが狂っている。
......Something had gone insane since yesterday.

昨夜の晩餐で真里亞が読み上げた、魔女ベアトリーチェの手紙。
There was that letter from the witch, Beatrice, that Maria had read aloud at last night's dinner.

…あの時から俺たちは、…いや、この屋敷やこの島が、何か奇妙な世界に取り込まれ始めている気がする…。
...Ever since that point, it feels like we've...no, like this whole mansion and this whole island have been getting more and more firmly locked inside some kind of bizarre world...

そう。思い返せば、あの手紙は魔女の誘いだったのだ。
この島の夜の支配者が、昼間の俺たちを、もうひとつの世界へ招待したのだ。
That's right. When I think back on it, that letter was an invitation from the witch.

The ruler of the nighttime island had invited us inhabitants of the day into another world.

電話も無線も途絶し、台風に閉ざされたこの島は、今や切り取られた異世界とすら言い切れる。
The phone and the radio had been interrupted and the island was shut off by the typhoon, so you really could call this place another world cut off from the real one by now.

……そう、今のこの島じゃ、魔女が手紙を送り、魔法陣に生贄が捧げられるのが当り前ってわけだ。
...Yeah, as this island is now, it's perfectly normal for a witch to send us letters and for human sacrifices to be offered up for the sake of magic circles.

………そして次は何が起こるってんだ？
山羊の仮面でも被ったおかしな連中が盆踊りでも始めるってのかよ…！
......So what will happen next?

Will some weird people wearing goat masks start doing the Bon Festival dance or something...?!

…あぁ、ダメだダメだ、わけがわかんねぇ…。
頭ん中がぐちゃぐちゃで、何を考えればいいのかもわかんねぇ…。
...Aah, it's hopeless, it's hopeless, I don't get it...

The inside of my head's all screwed up, and I don't even know what to think...

怒り、悲しみ。相反する感情が渦を巻き、俺を飲み込んでいく。
俺は抗うこともできず、…こうして両目を手で覆って飲み込まれていくに身と心を任せるだけだ………。
Anger, sadness. The opposing emotions all swirled up together, and they started to suck me in.

Unable to resist, ...I could do nothing but cover my eyes with my hands and trust to my mind and body as I started getting sucked in......

………俺の心が挫けかけた時、小さい頃の記憶が蘇る。
......As I started losing heart, I began to recall a memory from when I was small.

俺が小さかった頃のことさ。
It was from when I was very young.

テレビでオカルトものの怖い映画を見ちまって、ひとりでトイレにも行けなくなっちまった時だ。
I had unfortunately seen a scary occult movie on TV, and for a while, I hadn't even been able to go to the bathroom by myself.

…あんのクソ親父は大層笑ってこう言い放ちやがったぜ。
...That old bastard gave an exaggerated laugh and said this:

……なぁ戦人。
どうして悪魔だのオカルトだのってのを、わざわざこうして映画にすると思う？
......Hey, Battler.

Why do you think they go to all the trouble to make movies like this about demons and the occult and such?

ねぇからだよ。…そんな滑稽なもんは地球のどこにもねぇのさ。
ねぇから、わざわざ見たくて作るんだよ。
だから俺はオカルト映画なんて、ちゃんちゃら可笑しくて笑っちまうってんだ。
It's because they don't exist. ...Something that ridiculous can't be found anywhere on the planet.

Because they don't exist, people want to see them and go to a lot of effort making them.

That's why those occult movies just make me laugh.

俺に言わせりゃ、悪魔やら妖怪やらより、今年度の収支報告や、機嫌を悪くした女房の方が一億倍も怖ぇってもんだぜ。
If I were forced to choose, I'd say, rather than demons and monsters, this year's earnings call and angry wives are 100 million times scarier.

さらに言うぜ？　俺に言わせりゃな。
怖がるってのは、心と生活にゆとりのある連中の娯楽的感情なのさ。
I'll go further, okay? From my point of view...

Getting scared is a recreational emotion, something for people who've got room to relax both in their hearts and their lifestyles.

暇で暇でしょうがないから、連中は変わった感情で心を遊ばせたくて、悪魔だのオカルトだのって文化を作り出したんだよ。
They had so much free time, they didn't know what to do with it, so in order to entertain their mind with unusual emotions, people started creating a culture with demons and the occult and stuff.

………………………………………。
……まったくだぜ、俺は何をぼんやりしてやがったんだ。
すっかりヤラれちまってたぜ。
.....................

...Seriously, why have I been acting so damn thickheaded?

I was totally taken in.

………ふざけんじゃねぇ、ここは人間の世界さ。
魔女も悪魔も魔法陣も生贄も知ったこっちゃねぇさ。
......Don't try to mess with me, this is the human world.

I don't give a damn about witches, demons, magic circles and sacrifices.

俺の親父たちを殺した人間が、今まだこの島にいる。
ただそれだけのことじゃねぇか…！
The human who killed Dad and everyone else is still on this island.

That's all there is to it, right...?!

次に俺の心に語り掛けてきたのは霧江さんだった。
The next person who started speaking to my heart was Kyrie-san.

チェスや将棋ってね？
終盤の終盤、詰めの最後の段階に入れば入るほど、最善手は限られてくるのよ。
You see, in both chess and shogi...

When you reach the very, very last stage of the game and get closer and closer to cornering your opponent, the number of optimal moves you could possibly make gets smaller and smaller.

……だから、自分が追い詰めている、あるいは追い詰められているというその時、両者の手は限りなく読みやすくなるのよ。
...Therefore, if you're backing someone against the wall, or if someone's doing the same to you, both players' moves become infinitely easier to read.

つまり、完全に追い詰められて打つ手なしって思ったその時こそ、もっとも読みやすい瞬間なのよ。
In other words, when you're completely cornered and you think you have no moves left, that is the moment when it's easiest to read your opponent.

……でも、守勢に立った人間はどうしても考えが硬くなって相手の手を読むことにまで考えが至らない。
...However, when a person is forced into a defensive position, they can't help but lose their ability to think clearly, so they aren't able to get their minds around their opponent's moves.

……そういう時はね、“チェス盤をひっくり返す”の。
......That's when you `spin the chessboard around'.

俺は勢い良く、両手で自分の頬を叩く。
………すっかり目が覚めた。
With all my strength, I slapped my face with both hands.

......Now, my eyes were truly open.

さっぱりわからねぇと、完璧に追い詰められた今こそが“チェス盤をひっくり返す”タイミングじゃねぇのか…！
When you don't understand anything, and you're completely cornered just like I am now, isn't that the perfect time to `spin the chessboard around'...?!

守勢に立った俺たちには、犯人の目論見はさっぱり見当が付かない。
While on the defensive, we can't even guess at the culprit's scheme.

…ひっくり返して見てみたら、一体何が見えるのか。
...If we spin it around and look at it that way, just what might we see?

……まず、犯人は殺人を犯す時点で、島が台風に閉ざされているのを知っていた。
だから、殺人を実行しても翌朝にすぐ逃げられるわけではないことも理解していたはず。
...First off, at the time the culprit committed the murders, they knew the island was being cut off by the typhoon.

Therefore, they should've understood that even if they carried out the murders, they wouldn't be able to get away early the next morning.

つまり、犯人は退路の確保もなく殺人に踏み切ったわけだ。
In short, the culprit had begun without securing a way to escape.

しかもその死体は倉庫にぶち込み、ご丁寧にも、ここにありますよと妙な落書きでアピールまでしてくれやがった。
Furthermore, that bastard tossed the corpses in the storehouse, then was even kind enough to say `Here they are!' with that weird bit of graffiti.

つまり、やがて死体を見つけるだろう俺たちに“見せたい”のだ。
In other words, since we'd probably find the corpses sooner or later, they `wanted to show them to us'.

……もし俺たちが全員トボけていて、あの倉庫に気付かなかったら、犯人の目的は“達せられていなかったのではないか”。
......If we'd all been dim...and hadn't noticed the storage shed, the culprit's goal `would not have been achieved', would it?

へへ、こう考えてくると、犯人のやつめ。
朝からの俺たちの動きにハラハラしてやがっただろうよ。
Hehe, if you think about it this way, that bastard of a culprit...

Since this morning, they must've been watching our every move with bated breath.

何しろ、あの倉庫を見つけてくれなかったら、昨晩、さんざん苦労して準備したものがパーになるところだったんだからなぁ。
After all, if we hadn't been so kind as to discover what was on the storehouse, all of that hard work and preparation they did last night would've just gone `poof'.

犯人は、倉庫の死体を見せて俺たちに何を感じさせたいんだ？
What did the culprit want to make us feel by showing us the corpses in the storehouse?

６人の遺体はみな顔面を著しく破壊されていた。
…怨恨？　見せしめ？
遺体の破壊は死後だ。
All six of the bodies had their faces noticeably destroyed.

...Was it a grudge? A warning?

The defacement of the bodies had occurred after death.

つまり、殺人の手段じゃない。殺した相手への意味じゃない。
…それを“発見する者たちへの意味”だ。
So it hadn't been the means by which the culprit had killed. It didn't mean anything to those who had been killed.

...It `did have meaning to those who found the bodies'.

これだけ惨たらしく殺した、と、俺たちにアピールしたいわけだ。
The culprit wanted to make it appear that they had been killed so brutally.

は！　そう考えてくると、舐めんじゃねぇって気になってくるぜ。
誰が踊るかよ、ビビって下さいって言われて、ハイそうですかというわけにゃ行かねぇぜ。
Ha! After thinking this way, I really wanna tell that bastard to stop taking me so lightly.

Who'd just dance to that tune? If you're told `Please be scared', you can't just say `Really? Sure thing!'

…この右代宮戦人、入口はコチラと言われたら、窓から入り込みたくなる性分と来らぁ！
...When someone tells the great Ushiromiya Battler `the entrance is right here', I'm the kind of guy who'll start wanting to sneak in through the window!

次に気になるのは、シャッターの魔法陣もどきだ。
The next thing that had me concerned was that so-called magic circle on the shutter.

…オカルトに関しちゃ、祖父さま並みの知識を持っていることを披露してくれた真里亞も認める、本格派魔法陣と来た。
...As Maria, who had shown that her knowledge of the occult rivaled Grandfather's, had recognized, that magic circle was genuine.

そんなものを、傘を片手に真っ暗な中、時間を掛けて書いたってんだから、その手間と凝り性には恐れ入るねぇ。
They must have drawn that thing in pitch-black darkness, taking a lot of time and holding an umbrella in one hand. Isn't that amount of hard work and perfectionism impressive?

それだけの手間を掛けた意味は何だ？
What purpose would've been worth all of that effort?

…この屋敷でオカルト的なものがあったら、俺たちはほぼ自動的に祖父さまの関与を疑うだろう。
...If we were looking for a fan of the occult in this mansion, most likely, all of us would naturally suspect Grandfather.

俺たちに、“祖父さまが関わっていると思わせたい”ってのか？
Did they want to `make us think Grandfather was involved'?

だが、それだけが目的なら、魔法陣風のいい加減な落書きでもよかったはずだ。
どうせ俺たち素人にはそれが本格派かデタラメかなんて理解できないんだからな。
But if that's all they wanted, they could've just drawn any old scribble that looked like a magic circle.

It wasn't like any of us amateurs would be able to tell the difference between genuine and fake.

…しかし、魔法陣は本格派、しかもヘブライ語とやらでまで書かれてるって話だ。
...However, this magic circle was genuine, and furthermore, it had even been written in Hebrew.

………つまり、この魔法陣は、“オカルトの知識のある人間にだけは読み取れる”メッセージ性があるってことだ。
......So this magic circle had a message...`that could only be understood by someone with knowledge of the occult'.

メッセージってのはコミュニケーションのひとつだ。
……送ったら、相手からのリアクションを期待するものでもある。
A message is a form of communication.

......By sending it, they were hoping for a reaction.

…リアクション？
...A reaction?

………祖父さまは今、どういうわけか姿が見えない。
......For some reason, we couldn't find Grandfather now.

祖父さまがどうやってあのシャッターの魔法陣を見たのかは知らないが、…その結果のリアクションとして姿を消した、ということなのか…？
I don't know how Grandfather might've spotted the magic circle on the shutter, but did he choose to hide himself in reaction to that...?

いや、そう見せ掛けて俺たちに祖父さまの関与を疑わせようという罠なのか。
…どっちにも読めるぜ、うぜえ真似じゃねぇか。
No, was it a trap to make us suspect that Grandfather had participated?

...You could read it either way, damn that's annoying.

……犯人は、俺たちにこんなオカルトの真似事を見せて、どんなリアクションを期待してるってんだ…？
...What kind of reaction was the culprit hoping to get out of us by putting on this occult show...?

どうやらそこに、犯人の尻尾があるような気がするぜ…。
Somehow, that felt like the culprit's weak point...

昨夜の晩餐で真里亞が読み上げた、あのベアトリーチェの手紙の一部が脳裏に蘇る。
The letter from Beatrice that Maria had read aloud during last night's dinner sprang back into my mind.

……知恵比べをお楽しみ下さいとかのたまったやつだ。
...This was a freak who'd asked us to enjoy a battle of wits.

面白いじゃねぇか。
こいつは俺たちと魔女さまの知恵比べだ。
Isn't that interesting?

This is a battle of wits between us and the witch.

てめぇのオカルトごっこに俺たちが飲み込まれるのが早いか。
俺がてめぇの化けの皮を剥いでやるのが早いか。
Will we be sucked up by her occult game first?

Or will we pull off her fake skin first?

……台風が過ぎるまで、たっぷり一日あるわけだぜ。
楽しませてもらおうじゃねぇか…！
...There's a whole day until the typhoon passes.

Why not enjoy ourselves...?!

気付けば、客間の中は静まり返っていた。
I finally noticed that the inside of the parlor had gone quiet again.

みんな、思い思いのソファーに腰を沈め、何かを考え込んだり、イラついたり、落ち込んだりしている。
Everyone had sunk into their favorite sofas, some deep in thought, some irritated, some acting depressed.

真里亞はさっきからずっとそうであったかのように、再びテレビの前に戻り観賞を続けている。
Maria was once again enjoying the TV as if she'd never left it.

…退屈な番組よりＣＭの方が楽しいらしく、うーうーきゃっきゃと喜んでいた。
It looked like she found the commercials more fun than the boring program, and she happily yelled `uu-uu-' and giggled.

そんなみんなの様子を、俺はジロリとひとりひとり眺める。
１９人目などいないなら、
………この部屋の中に、犯人がいるからだ。
I stared at each person's appearance in turn.

If there isn't a 19th person,

......the culprit must be in this room.

…今は、夏妃伯母さんが使用人たちと屋敷内の見回りをしているところだったか。
...Right now, Aunt Natsuhi's searching the mansion with the servants, right?

……なら、この部屋の中に、ではない。
……この屋敷の中に、と言うべきだ。
......Then we shouldn't say `in this room.'

......`In this mansion'...is where the culprit has to be.

　…何しろ、夏妃伯母さんだって黒幕の可能性はあるし、
…使用人が下手人である可能性は未だ否定できない。
...After all, it's possible Aunt Natsuhi was behind this,

...and we still can't deny that one of the servants might be the killer.




………誰もがクロの可能性があった。
......Anyone could be guilty.

しかし、夏妃伯母さんたちは遅いな…。
Still, Aunt Natsuhi and the rest sure are taking their time...

確かに狭くはない屋敷だが、戸締りを見て回るだけにしては少し時間を掛け過ぎではないだろうか…。
Of course, it's not a small mansion, but isn't this taking a little too long just to walk around, checking the windows and doors...?

そう思った頃、夏妃伯母さんたちは帰ってきた。
誰かが欠けていたりはしない。
……安心しようとしたのも束の間。
全員がぎょっとして夏妃伯母さんを見る…。
Just as I was thinking this, Aunt Natsuhi and the rest returned.

Not one of them was missing.

...But our relief was short-lived.

Everyone looked at Aunt Natsuhi in shock...

……絵羽伯母さんに聞かされた話が蘇る。
...The talk I'd had with Aunt Eva started to creep back into my mind.

犯人たちは、親父たちを６人も一度に殺せるほどの人数、あるいは武器を用意していた可能性があると。
The possibility that the culprits had enough in numbers or weapons to kill all of those six at once...

「………驚かせてしまいましたね。万が一に備えて持ってきたものです。」
"...Forgive me if I've startled you. I brought this to be prepared for the worst."

夏妃伯母さんが手にしていたのは、ライフル銃だったからだ。
After all, that thing in Aunt Natsuhi's hand was a rifle.

ぱっと見る限りは、猟銃とよく似たシルエットだったが、全長が非常に短く、何だか子どもサイズの鉄砲というイメージだった。
At a glance, its silhouette looked a lot like a hunting gun, but it was unusually short and kinda looked like a kid-sized weapon.

だが、その重厚感は、この銃が断じて子どもの玩具ではないことを語っている。
However, it had a weightiness to it that made it clear it was no kid's toy.

「…それは金蔵さんの銃ですな…？」
"...That gun is Kinzo-san's, isn't it...?"

「ご存知でしたか。そうです。お父様の古いコレクションの中にあったことを思い出し、探し出してきました。」
"Did you know about it? That's right. I remembered it was in Father's old collection, and I managed to find it."

「ひゅぅ！　すっげぇ…。夏妃さん、それホンモノなんすか？」
"Whoa! Awesome... Natsuhi-san, is that thing real?"

「えぇ、本物です。実弾を発砲できますよ。昔、お父様は野鳥を追い払うのに使ったりしていました。」
"Yes, it's real. It can fire live ammunition. Long ago, Father used it to scare away wild birds."

「……あら懐かしい。どこから出てきたんやら。私がいくら触らせてって言っても、指一本触れさせてくれなかったやつよぅ。」
"......Ah, that takes me back. Where did you find that thing...? No matter how much I asked him to let me touch it, he never let me lay even one finger on it."

「へぇ…。祖父さま、こんなの持ってたんですか…。知らなかったですよ。」
"Oh... Grandfather had one of these...? I didn't know that."

「お父様は昔、西部劇にどっぷり浸かってたことがあってね。あの世代はこういうライフル銃が大好きなのよぅ。」
"Long ago, Grandfather was really addicted to cowboy films. That generation really liked this kind of rifle."

「ウィンチェスターですか？　でも、こんな短い仕様のは初めて見ました。」
"Is that a Winchester? But I've never seen one that short before."

「あーーッ！　思い出したわ、その銃ッ！
"Ah! I remember, it's that gun!

懐かしいなぁ、拳銃宿無しでスチーム・マックィーンがぶっ放しとったやつだわ！！　お父さんも渋いなぁ…！」
That really takes me back. That's the one Steam McQueen fired off in Wanted: Alive or Dead!! Father sure has good taste...!"

「………お館様がだいぶ昔に、アメリカより特別に取り寄せさせたものです。…ご覧の通り実銃ですので、どうかこの件はご内密にお願いいたします…。」
"......It is an item the Master ordered specially from America, long ago. ...As you can see, it is a working gun, so please don't tell anyone about this..."

「手に入れられたばかりの頃は、大層気に入られておりまして。撃つより、薬莢を出す動作が面白いらしくて、裏の森でいろいろとカッコつけて遊んでおられたもんですよ。ほっほっほっほ…。」
"He was quite fond of it right after he managed to acquire it. It seems the workings that ejected the cartridges were more interesting to him than shooting it, and he played around with it back in the forest all the time. Hohohohoh..."

「……しかし物騒ねぇ。そんなものまで持ち出しちゃうのかしらぁ？」
"...Still, it's rather disturbing. Are you sure you should be dragging this out?"

「万が一に備えてです。………賊はおそらく１人ではないでしょう。しかも、主人たちを６人も殺した恐ろしい相手です。……私には主人に代わって、皆さんを明日まで守る義務がありますので。」
"This is to prepare for the worst. ...There was probably more than one offender involved. Furthermore, those horrible people killed six of us, including my husband. ...I have a responsibility to protect everyone until tomorrow, in my husband's place."

夏妃さんはそう言うと、どっかりとソファーに腰を下ろし大きく溜め息をつく。
As Natsuhi-san said this, she slumped down into one of the sofas and took a deep breath.

屋敷内の戸締りの確認と、…あと祖父さまを探すということになっていたはずだ。
She had been trying to find Grandfather, ...as well as check the doors and windows.

そして祖父さまと一緒じゃないところを見ると、その行方は未だわからないというようだった。
Since Grandfather wasn't with her, she probably still didn't know where he was.

「…屋敷内の戸締りは厳重に確認してきました。ですが、万が一ということもあります。皆、なるべくここに一緒にいた方がいいでしょう。」
